ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Guided modes in asymmetric graphene waveguides

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Department of Physics, College of Sciences

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: An asymmetric quantum well in graphene can act as a slab waveguide for electron waves in a manner analogous to the electromagnetic waves in dielectrics. Guided modes and the probability current density are analyzed in the graphene electron waveguide induced by asymmetric electrostatic potential. The modes in an asymmetric graphene waveguide include guided modes, “cover modes”, “substrate modes” and “radiation modes”. The conditions for a guided mode are quantified. It is found that the fundamental mode is absent when both the Klein tunneling and classical motion are present. The confinement of electrons for lower order mode is stronger than for higher order mode. We hope that these characteristics in asymmetric graphene waveguide can provide potential applications in graphene-based waveguide devices.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Since the mean-free path approaches the order of micron at room temperature in the ballistic regime, the electrons can refract, reflect and interfere in a manner analogous to electromagnetic waves in dielectrics. Many similarities exist between optics and electronics. The analogy with optics may provide potential application for electrons. Electron waveguide made of semiconductor is one example of the theoretical and technological implementation of this similarity [1]. Conventional p–n junctions are not suitable for precision manipulation of electron beams. The two-dimensional (2D) gapless semiconductor, graphene, has many priorities in electron waveguide [2]. It has attracted a great deal of attention both in experimental and theoretical research due to its unique properties [3–7]. The carrier density can be tuned well by means of electrical gates [8–10] or doping of the underlying substrate [11, 12], so the controllable ballistic p–n–p junctions can be realized [13]. The propagation of electrons along the p–n–p junction may resemble rays in optical waveguide [14–17]. The p–n–p quantum well junctions in graphene can act as slab electron waveguides.

The graphene waveguides induced by electric field or magnetic potential which can strongly confine the Dirac fermions in graphene have been investigated [18–23]. It has been demonstrated that square quantum wells in graphene can confine mass-less Dirac fermions and the confined states are investigated in detail [24, 25]. It is notable that some graphene waveguides are induced by sharply-terminated or square well potentials [18–23, 26–28]. Recently, the smooth one-dimensional potential has been proposed to confine the electrons in graphene [29–32]. It is found that there is a threshold value of the characteristic potential strength when the first confined mode appears. The guided modes in strongly coupled double waveguides based on graphene have also been discussed [33, 34]. Furthermore, waveguide based on the graphene nanoribbons and antidot lattice waveguides based on nanostructured graphene have been investigated [35, 36]. The guided modes in graphene can be confined by velocity barriers [37]. In experiments, an extension of using both n and p carrier types to create electronic analogs of optical devices has been realized. They use the gate-controlled density of both p and n carrier types in graphene to demonstrate the electronic analog of fiber-optic guiding [13].

It is essential to investigate the electron waveguiding characteristics in asymmetric waveguide in graphene since the symmetric waveguide is an exceptional case. However, works about the asymmetric graphene waveguides are very few. Peng et al. have investigated the oscillating guided modes in graphene-based asymmetric waveguides [26]. Despite all this research for the oscillating guided modes, other electron waveguiding characteristics in the general structure made of asymmetric graphene quantum well, such as the conditions for the guided modes, the modes cutoff and the energy spectrum, have not been discussed. In this paper, we investigate the asymmetric graphene waveguide which is induced by asymmetric electrostatic potential. We quantify the conditions for the guided modes in an asymmetric graphene waveguide. The guided modes can be generated in three ways in asymmetric quantum well, which are different from those in the symmetric quantum well. We will discuss types of guided modes and unguided modes, the cutoff condition, and the dispersion relation governing the electron guided modes.

Section2.Heading: Configuration
Section2.Para:
An asymmetric graphene quantum well structure acting as a slab waveguide is shown in Fig. 1. The waveguide configuration of the p–n–p junction can be fabricated by applying a voltage to the back gate and the top gate on the sheet of graphene [8]. By adjusting the voltage, an asymmetric p–n–p quantum well can be formed. Although it is a waveguide for electron waves, we can still denote the three regions as substrate (s), film (f), and cover (c) similarly to that in the slab optical waveguide. The potential profile of the three regions is denoted by 1
$$ V(x) = \left \{ \begin{array}{@{}l@{\quad}l} V_{\mathrm{s}} & x < 0 \\ V_{\mathrm{f}} & 0 < x < d \\ V_{\mathrm{c}} & x > d. \end{array} \right . $$ Here, V f, V s and V c are associated with the height of the film, substrate and cover, respectively. The width of the waveguide is d. In this paper, we set V f=0 meV, V s=50 meV, V c=75 meV and the width d=200 nm. The electron wave in the film reflects at the interfaces back and forth with the zigzag angle θ, and the guided wave propagates along the y axis. In this model the microscopic details of the interaction effects such as the inter-valley coupling are neglected, since the sample width w is assumed large enough to neglect the edge effects [38, 39]. There is no inter-valley scattering in the potential steps as the distance between the valleys is reciprocal to space: |K−K′|∼1/a, where a=1.42 Å is the lattice scale [39, 40].

Section2.Heading: Critical angles
Section2.Para:
The magnitude of the electron wave vector in the three regions can be expressed as: 2
$$ k_{j} = | E - V_{j} | / \hbar v_{\mathrm{F}} = s_{j}(E - V_{j}) / \hbar v_{\mathrm{F}}, $$ where the subscript j=s,f,c represents the substrate, film, and cover regions, respectively, E is the electron energy, V
j is the electrostatic potential, and
$s_{j} =\operatorname{sign}(E - V_{j})$ . Similarly to the Snell’s law of geometrical optics, we can obtain the equivalent of Snell’s law for electron waves in the presence of electrostatic potential in graphene. For incidence upon the cover–film interface, as shown in Fig. 1, the Snell’s law can be expressed as 3
$$ \frac{\sin \theta_{\mathrm{c}}}{\sin \theta_{\mathrm{f}}} = \frac{k_{\mathrm{f}}}{k_{\mathrm{c}}}. $$ Thus the critical angle at the cover–film interface can be obtained: 4
$$ \theta_{\mathrm{cf}} = \arcsin \bigl( \vert E - V_{\mathrm{c}} \vert / \vert E - V_{\mathrm{f}} \vert \bigr). $$ The condition |E−V c|/|E−V f|<1 should be satisfied to make (4) meaningful. The total internal reflection happens when the incidence energy satisfies V c/2<E<V c or V c<E, corresponding to the Klein tunneling and classical motion, respectively. For an electron wave with incidence angle θ>θ cf, the wave will be totally internally reflected. At steady state, the entire electron current is reflected back into the film, while the electron wave function decays exponentially into the cover. Similarly, the substrate–film critical angle is 5
$$ \theta_{\mathrm{sf}} = \arcsin \bigl(\vert E - V_{\mathrm{s}} \vert / \vert E - V_{\mathrm{f}} \vert \bigr), $$ with the condition V s/2<E<V s or V s<E.

Guided modes exist when the electron wave is totally internally reflected both at the cover–film interface and the substrate–film interface. For a guided mode, the zigzag angle θ must be larger than each θ cf and θ sf: 6
$$ \theta > \max (\theta_{\mathrm{cf}},\theta_{\mathrm{sf}}). $$ The critical angles θ cf and θ sf are shown in Fig. 2 on a plot of zigzag angle θ versus the incidence energy E.
Fig. 2
The critical angles of θ sf and θ cf on a plot of zigzag angle vs. the incident electron energy. The regions of guided modes, radiation modes, substrate modes and cover modes are presented. Here, the width of the waveguide is d=200 nm, and V f=0 meV, V s=50 meV, V c=75 meV

Section2.Heading: Types of guided modes and unguided “modes”
Section2.Para: As mentioned previously, when E<V s/2, the total internal reflection would not occur for any incidence angle. When the energy increases to V s/2<E<V c/2, and the zigzag angle θ>θ sf, the electron wave starts to refract into the cover (rather than exponentially decay) and total internal reflection only occurs at the substrate–film interface. This is called a cover “mode”, which is not a true guided mode. The range of zigzag angle satisfies Eq. (6) and the energy E>V c/2 corresponds to the region of allowed guided modes. For θ cf<θ<θ sf, the electron wave will be totally reflected at the cover–film interface and refracted into the substrate, which is called as substrate “mode.” If θ<min(θ cf,θ sf), a radiation “mode” appears.

Section2.Heading: Types of cutoff
Section2.Para:
The propagation constant, β, of the guided mode is the same as the component of the wave vector parallel to the boundary, β=k
y . Thus, it is given by 7
$$ \beta = \vert E - V_{j} \vert \sin \theta / \hbar v_{\mathrm{F}}. $$ The maximum electron propagation constant in the substrate, film and cover regions is 8a
$$\begin{aligned} &{\beta_{\mathrm{s}} = k_{\mathrm{s}} = \vert E - V_{\mathrm{s}} \vert / \hbar v_{\mathrm{F}},} \end{aligned}$$
8b
$$\begin{aligned} &{\beta_{\mathrm{f}} = k_{\mathrm{f}} = \vert E - V_{\mathrm{f}} \vert / \hbar v_{\mathrm{F}},} \end{aligned}$$
8c
$$\begin{aligned} &{\beta_{\mathrm{c}} = k_{\mathrm{c}} = \vert E - V_{\mathrm{c}} \vert / \hbar v_{\mathrm{F}}.} \end{aligned}$$

These three propagation constant relationships are presented in Fig. 3. For a given energy E, the propagation constant of a guided mode can be no larger than that given by Eq. (8b). The region to the left of the black curve corresponds to the evanescent modes, and the allowed guided modes must lie to the right of this black curve.
Fig. 3
Electron guided mode propagation constant as a function of incidence energy of electron. The physical parameters are the same as in Fig. 2

The intersection of β f and β s occurs at an energy E sf which is given by 9a
$$ E_{\mathrm{sf}} = (V_{\mathrm{s}} + V_{\mathrm{f}}) / 2. $$ This energy is equivalent to the substrate–film critical angle θ sf=90∘. At this energy, the waveguide can no longer guide an electron wave even if it is at grazing incidence along the walls of the waveguide. The intersection of β f and β c occurs at the energy 9b
$$ E_{\mathrm{cf}} = (V_{\mathrm{c}} + V_{\mathrm{f}}) / 2, $$ which is equivalent to the energy at cover–film critical angle θ cf=90∘. Similarly, the intersection of β c and β s occurs at the energy 9c
$$ E_{\mathrm{cs}} = (V_{\mathrm{c}} + V_{\mathrm{s}}) / 2. $$ Cutoff for the guided modes can occur when the total internal reflection no longer occurs at the substrate–film or cover–film boundary. In this situation, the electron wave is refracted into the substrate or cover region. Cutoff of the guided modes in asymmetric graphene waveguide can occur in two ways: (i) α c=0 and (ii) α s=0. The α
c and α
s are the decay constants in the cover region and substrate region, respectively. In a guide mode, the wave function in the channel is sinusoidal while it is exponential decay function outside the channel. When α c(α s) decreases to zero, the wave function outside the channel is no longer evanescent, and the electron is refracted into the cover (substrate).

Section2.Heading: Energy versus wave vector dispersion
Section2.Para:
The wave function Ψ A and Ψ B, which respectively represents the smooth enveloping function at the A, B sublattice sites of graphene, can be expressed as
$\varPsi_{\mathrm{A},\mathrm{B}} = \psi_{\mathrm{A},\mathrm{B}}(x)\mathrm{e}^{ik_{y}y}$ due to the translation invariance in the y direction. ψ A,B(x) satisfies the Helmholtz-like equation 10
$$ \frac{d^{2}\psi_{\mathrm{A},\mathrm{B}}}{dx^{2}} + \biggl[ \frac{(E - V(x))^{2}}{\hbar^{2}v_{\mathrm{F}}^{2}} - k_{y}^{2} \biggr]\psi_{\mathrm{A},\mathrm{B}} = 0. $$ In Eq. (10), the first term in the square brackets is k 2. The dispersion relation is 11
$$ E = V(x) \pm \hbar v_{\mathrm{F}}k. $$ This linear-dispersion relation is different from that in semiconductor quantum well [41]. The slope of the electromagnetic wave dispersion curve depends on the refractive index, while that of the dispersion curve in graphene is a constant, as shown in Eq. (11).

$\alpha_{\mathrm{s}} = \sqrt{k_{y}^{2} - k_{\mathrm{s}}^{2}}$ and
$\alpha_{\mathrm{c}} = \sqrt{k_{y}^{2} - k_{\mathrm{c}}^{2}}$ are the decay constants in the substrate region and cover region, respectively.

Applying the continuity of wave function at the two interfaces of the asymmetric waveguide, we obtain the dispersion equation: 14
$$ \tan (k_{x}d) = \frac{s_{\mathrm{c}}k_{\mathrm{s}}(\alpha_{\mathrm{c}} + k_{y})k_{x} + s_{\mathrm{s}}k_{\mathrm{c}}(\alpha_{\mathrm{s}} - k_{y})k_{x}}{s_{\mathrm{s}}k_{\mathrm{c}}(\alpha_{\mathrm{s}} - k_{y})k_{y} - s_{\mathrm{c}}k_{\mathrm{s}}(\alpha_{\mathrm{c}} + k_{y})k_{y} + s_{\mathrm{f}}k_{\mathrm{f}}k_{\mathrm{c}}k_{\mathrm{s}} - s_{\mathrm{f}}s_{\mathrm{c}}s_{\mathrm{s}}(\alpha_{\mathrm{s}} - k_{y})(\alpha_{\mathrm{c}} + k_{y})}. $$ The right-hand side of (14) should be rewritten as a function of k
x
d to reveal the guided modes: 15
$$ F(k_{x}d) = \frac{(f_{1} + f_{2})(k_{x}d)}{(f_{2} - f_{1})f_{3} + f_{4} - s_{\mathrm{f}}(k_{\mathrm{f}}d)f_{1}f_{2} / (k_{\mathrm{s}}dk_{\mathrm{c}}d)}. $$ Here,
$$\begin{aligned} &{f_{1} = s_{\mathrm{c}}(k_{\mathrm{s}}d) \Bigl( \sqrt {f_{3}^{2} - (k_{\mathrm{c}}d)^{2}} + f_{3} \Bigr),}\\ &{ f_{2} = s_{\mathrm{s}}(k_{\mathrm{c}}d) \Bigl( \sqrt{f_{3}^{2} - (k_{\mathrm{s}}d)^{2}} + f_{3} \Bigr),}\\ &{f_{3} = \sqrt{(k_{\mathrm{f}}d)^{2} - (k_{x}d)^{2}},\qquad f_{4} = s_{\mathrm{f}}(k_{\mathrm{f}}d) (k_{\mathrm{s}}d) (k_{\mathrm{c}}d).} \end{aligned}$$

The dispersion equation can be rewritten as 16
$$ k_{x}d - \arctan \bigl(F(k_{x}d)\bigr) = v\pi,\quad v = 0,1,2, \ldots . $$ If V c=V s=∞, the dispersion equation (16) simplifies to k
x
d=vπ or 17
$$ E = V(x) \pm \hbar v_{\mathrm{F}}\sqrt{(v\pi / d)^{2} + k_{y}^{2}}, $$ which is not a linear-dispersion equation any more [24]. Furthermore, if V c=V s, there is s c=s s and α c=α s, the asymmetric waveguide turns into a symmetric one, and the dispersion equation (14) changes to that in the symmetric case [18]: 18
$$ \tan (k_{x}d) = \frac{s_{\mathrm{f}}s_{\mathrm{c}}(k_{x}d)\sqrt{(k_{\mathrm{f}}d)^{2} - (k_{x}d)^{2} - (k_{\mathrm{c}}d)}}{(k_{\mathrm{f}}d)(k_{\mathrm{c}}d) - s_{\mathrm{f}}s_{\mathrm{c}} [ (k_{\mathrm{f}}d)^{2} - (k_{x}d)^{2} ]}. $$

The decay constants α s and α c can be rewritten as
$\alpha_{\mathrm{s}} = \sqrt{k_{\mathrm{f}}^{2} - k_{x}^{2} - k_{\mathrm{s}}^{2}}$ and
$\alpha_{\mathrm{c}} = \sqrt{k_{\mathrm{f}}^{2} - k_{x}^{2} - k_{\mathrm{c}}^{2}}$ . To get an asymmetric quantum well waveguide in graphene, α s and α c should be real, thus, k
x
d should satisfy
$k_{x}d < \min (\sqrt{k_{\mathrm{f}}^{2} - k_{\mathrm{c}}^{2}} d,\sqrt{k_{\mathrm{f}}^{2} - k_{\mathrm{s}}^{2}} d )$ .
(i)
When V c/2<E<V s, s c s f=1, we get one of the dispersion equations. In this case, the electron makes an interband tunneling from an electron-like to hole-like, which corresponds to the case of Klein tunneling. This is similar to the case of ss′=−1 in symmetric waveguide in graphene [18].
(ii)
When E>V s, s c s f=1, the electron makes an interband tunneling from an electron-like to another electron-like at both sides of the quantum well, which corresponds to the case of classical motion. It is similar to the case of ss′=1 in symmetric waveguide in graphene [18].
The guided modes in the former two cases have similar characteristics with those in symmetric waveguide. One can find more details about the oscillating guided modes for the two cases in graphene-based asymmetric waveguide [26]. In the following, we will focus on the guided modes and the probability current density distribution for the third case of V s<E<V c in the asymmetric waveguide.
(iii)
When V s<E<V c, s c s f=−1, we get another dispersion equation. At the substrate–film interface, the electron makes an interband tunneling from an electron-like to hole-like, which corresponds to the case of Klein tunneling; however, at the cover–film interface, the electron makes an interband tunneling from an electron-like to another electron-like, which corresponds to the case of classical motion. It can be seen from Fig. 4 that there are five intersections, which denote the existence of the guided modes. In a guided mode, the electron wave function is oscillating in the film while it is exponentially decaying in the cover and substrate regions. The profiles of the electron wave function corresponding to the three intersections are presented in Fig. 5. It is clearly seen that the states of ψ A and −iψ B have similar characteristics. Using the optical waveguide terminology, we define the guide modes by the number of the nodes of the spinor wave function, where the spinor components ψ A and ψ B represent electrons and holes, respectively. It can be seen from Fig. 5 that the asymmetric electron waveguide supports the first-order, second-order, third-order, fourth-order and fifth-order modes. In this case, the fundamental mode does not exist at all, which is similar to the phenomenon in the symmetric graphene waveguide in the case of Klein tunneling [18] and that in the asymmetric left-handed material waveguides [42]. In addition, the shift between the two wave functions is also demonstrated, because the corresponding electron velocities of ψ A and ψ B are different.

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: Similarly to the optical waveguide, the electron wave in an asymmetric graphene waveguide is totally internally reflected at both sides of the quantum well. The conditions for the asymmetric waveguide are quantified. Applying the continuity of wave function at the interfaces, the dispersion Eq. (14), governing the guided modes for the asymmetric waveguide, has been developed.

There are three ways to generate guided modes in asymmetric quantum wells. (i) Only Klein tunneling exists. The incidence energy is smaller than the two barriers. (ii) Only classical motion exists. The electron energy is larger than the two potential barriers. (iii) Both Klein tunneling and classical motion are present, which means the incidence energy is higher than the one barrier while lower than the other. In the case of (i) and (ii) in asymmetric graphene waveguide, the guided modes have similar characteristics with those in symmetric waveguide. In the case (iii), the fundamental mode is absent. The plots of probability current density show that the confinement of electrons for lower order mode is stronger than that for higher order mode. We hope these features in the asymmetric quantum well waveguide will provide a basis for designing graphene quantum wave devices and controlling the electronic transport in graphene.
